description.en: The course consists of two modules. The first module provides an overview of ethical theories, moral relativism, moral dilemmas, and their relevance to the ethics of technology and professionalism. The second module comprises six online seminars for which students choose topics from the following selection: biomedical technologies, populations and technology, sex and technologies, automation, AI and ethics, military technologies, cost of technologies, surveillance, and data ethics.
description.et: Aine koosneb kahest osast. Esimene moodul annab ülevaate eetikateooriatest, moraalirelativismist, moraalidilemmadest ning nende olulisusest tehnoloogia eetikas. Teises moodulis valivad tudengid ise kuus teemat väljapakutute hulgast (kõik keskenduvad kindlate tehnoloogiate ühiskondlikele ning eetilistele aspektidele): biomeditsiinilised tehnoloogiad, populatsioon ning tehnoloogiad, seks ja tehnoloogiad, automatiseerimine, tehisintellekti eetika, sõjalised tehnoloogiad, tehnoloogiate hind, jälgimistehnoloogiad, andme-eetika.

objectives.en:
*	To learn to reflect upon the ethical and social aspects concerning technology R&D.
*	To learn about the ethical theories and some fundamental concepts that help such reflections.
*	To learn to reflect upon and justify one's own ethical beliefs (in relation to technology R&D).

independent_work.et:
INTRO module (more detailed instructions available in Moodle):

1. Introductory seminar
- Prepare for the seminar by watching an introductory video (7:15) and by reading the Study Guide 2025.
2. E-learning: ethics theories
- Watch the video lecture (24:11) on ethics theories and read Jonathan Wolff's book chapter "Safety". 
- Post a comment (about 500 words) on homework forum about the reading.
- Provide a short commentary on another student's post.
3. E-learning: the challenge of moral relativism
- Watch the introductory video on moral relativism (13:13)
- Read Chapter 10 of the book Engineering ethics. Concepts and Cases by CE Harris Jr, MS Pritchard, MJ Rabin's (2009)
- Answer two questions on homework forum.
4. E-learning: on value dilemmas
- Start by solving moral dilemmas and test your own intuitions with the MIT moral machine (https://www.moralmachine.net/).
- Read the short intro to moral dilemmas (excerpt from The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, article Moral Dilemmas, by Terrance McConnell).
- Select one case from a list of real-life cases, each portraying a dilemma. Identify the relevant values at stake, and provide your own justified solution for the dilemma.
5. E-learning: professional engineering ethics
- Read El-Zein's article "As engineers, we must consider the ethical implications of our work" (The Guardian, 2013).
- Read Chapter 1 of the book "Engineering Ethics. Concepts and Cases" by CE Harris Jr, MS Pritchard, MJ Rabin's (2009).
- Find an academic article that discusses an ethical issue in engineering, post a short description of the key ideas presented in the article and your own critical remarks on the article (300-500 words).
- Comment on another student's post.

In the TOPICS module, students elect 6 out of 9 topics, each of which will be discussed in a seminar. Before each seminar, students are asked to read/watch/listen to the materials provided in Moodle.

description.et:
INTRO MODULE. A completed homework assignment is one where: a) all questions are answered and tasks completed, b) the answers are well-justified with references to the materials provided, and possibly external sources, and c) there are no significant misunderstandings regarding the subject matter.

TOPICS MODULE. Active contribution to six online seminar discussions, drawing on the themes covered in the INTRO module, preparatory materials, and personal or professional experience. Inactivity (i.e., failing to express your views, thoughts or ideas, and not making any attempt
to justify them) in a seminar will result in an F for that seminar. Two seminar Fs will result in an F for the entire course.

grade_preconditions.et: Participate in the introductory seminar and complete all four homework assignments in the INTRO module. Active contribution to six online seminar discussions. If you have a hearing or vision impairment that may affect your ability to fully participate in the online seminars, please contact the course instructor to discuss appropriate accommodations.

grade_evaluation.et: There are four written homework assignments in the INTRO module. Completing these four assignments is a prerequisite for entering the TOPICS module. Assessment is based on contribution to six seminar discussions.
